poll_list.title: Inclusion Poll for Staking Rewards (MIP49) - May 10, 2021

content.content: MIP49: Staking Rewards  Preamble MIP#: 49 Title: Staking Rewards Author(s): Payton Rose (@prose11), Sam MacPherson (@hexonaut) Contributors:@LongForWisdom, @juan, @Elihu Type: General Status: Rejected Date Proposed: 2021-02-03 Date Ratified: <yyyy-mm-dd> Dependencies: Replaces:   References  The initial idea for Staking Rewards can be found in this forum post    Sentence Summary MIP49 proposes the creation of Staking Rewards that would allow the Maker community to reward MKR holders for locking their MKR tokens in Governance.  Paragraph Summary This MIP covers the creation of a Staking Rewards process for MKR token holders, designed to distribute DAI as a percentage of protocol profits. MIP49 would entitle MKR holders to a share of this percentage based on the weight of their MKR staked in the Governance Contract. The implementation method is intentionally left open so that the protocol can adopt a more efficient method of distributing rewards, should one be developed.  Component Summary MIP49c1: Staking Rewards Structure Defines the scope of Staking Rewards. MIP49c2: Adjusting the Staking Reward Percentage Parameter Clarifies how changes may be made to the Stake Reward Percentage parameter. MIP49c3: Potential Risks Defines potential avenues for abuse that should be considered if Staking Rewards are enabled.  Motivation The main motivation for this proposal is to help secure the MakerDAO Protocol. The amount of MKR available to borrow on the open market remains a security concern. MKR token borrowers do not have economically aligned incentives with the Maker Protocol, and represent a danger even if there is not enough MKR available on the lending markets to pass a malicious action. By offering incentives to MKR holders who lock their MKR tokens in Governance, this proposal hopes to encourage MKR holders to participate in securing the protocol. The following outcomes are also expected:  It should provide a more direct value accrual mechanism compared to the burner by distributing assets to MKR holders engaged in Governance. It should encourage more members to participate in the governance process, as the opportunity cost from locking MKR tokens is reduced. It should act as a partial subsidy to the gas cost of participating in Maker Governance.   Specification / Proposal Details MIP49c1 - Staking Rewards Structure Staking Rewards will be “opt-in”. Users locking their MKR tokens in governance will be able to choose to either receive Staking Rewards or not. The Staking Rewards will be distributed in DAI. The amount of DAI distributed as Staking Rewards will be directly tied to the MKR burn, with a portion of DAI that would have been used to buyback and burn MKR being diverted to Staking Rewards. The percentage of funds redirected will be controlled by Governance and referred to as the Stake Reward Percentage parameter. Proceeds from the Stake Reward Percentage will be split among opted-in holders, based on their relative weight in the Governance Contract. Note: MKR holders should be aware of any tax and legal implications in their jurisdiction relevant to opting-in to Staking Rewards before electing to do so. MIP49c2: Adjusting the Staking Reward Percentage Parameter The Stake Reward Percentage parameter will be expressed a percentage, between 0 and 100, and will dictate what percentage of funds otherwise destined for the flapper (surplus auction) will be instead spent on Staking Rewards. For example, if Governance were to set Stake Reward Percentage to 25%, for every 100 DAI the protocol generates when the Surplus Buffer is full, 25 DAI would be diverted to reward MKR tokens staked in the Governance Contract. Adjustments to the Stake Reward Percentage parameter may be made through the Weekly Governance Cycle, allowing for the community to respond quickly to changing market conditions. MIP49c3 - Potential Risks Directly rewarding locked MKR in the governance contract introduces risks to the Maker Protocol that have the potential to result in a protocol shutdown or a fork in certain scenarios. At the time of writing, actively-voting MKR comes to at most 10% of the total vote weight. The introduction of voting rewards encourages more MKR to be locked in the governance contract, which in turn reduces the barrier for that MKR to vote. If enough MKR becomes active in governance solely due to the staking reward incentive, this introduces the risk of successful proposals that increase the staking reward beyond what is beneficial for the Maker Protocol in pursuit of immediate, short-term gain for MKR Holders. This outcome could happen gradually or more quickly, and could take a number of forms. It is strongly recommended that MKR Holders that wish to ensure the long term growth and stability of the Maker Protocol view the following types of proposal with skepticism:  Proposals that increase the percentage of surplus revenue that is diverted from MKR burn to Staking Rewards. Proposals that seek to detach Staking Rewards from the surplus revenue generated by the MKR Protocol. Proposals that mint MKR for distribution as Staking Rewards. Proposals that by other means increase Staking Rewards in an inflationary way.  It is essential that the Staking Reward mechanism maintains the incentive alignment between MKR Holders receiving the reward, passive MKR Holders and the Maker Protocol as a whole.

content.content: So the idea here is to let the community debate having Governance Rewards and then if it is approved, have the community propose the specifics. There are a lot of potential implications so I don’t want to get too far ahead of myself and start throwing out numbers that may or may not make sense by the time we are able to implement them. With that said, the general discussion has been around utilizing something like the Keg to stream rewards based on a percent of the “profit” (really excess revenue to operational actions) that would otherwise be headed to the Flapper. With the intention that the rate is proportional to the amount of MKR on the borrow markets. That way when the Hat is potentially vulnerable (ie there’s a lot of MKR out there to borrow from) MKR holders are fiscally encouraged to deposit their tokens in governance, and that incentive would decrease as the MKR on the borrow markets dried up. All just hypothetical at this point, but I thought that was a good question and that it might inform votes to know how this is being thought of in terms of utilization.

content.content: Assumption:  DAI as a global USD-pegged settlement tool is decentralised & uncensorable only if its governance committee shares those same characteristics Maker is decentralised, antifragile, resistant by design to government powers as long as its voters act selflessly in favour for a global payment system with minimized/no nationalistic biases  Yet here I am, seeing a lot of argumentation referring to local tax laws, potentially hindering true global innovation. If a design similar to CRVs (i.e. MKR → potentially timelocked veMKR) were to be seen as the soundest solution for incentive alignments across all timeframes, then I don’t see how local fiscality should play a role in any argument. It feels like we’re trying to build a dirtroad around a forest instead of making space for a proper & efficient concrete highway through it. (i.e. harm minimization by catering to personal/local tax preferences VS disregard for localities as a global framework is needed for a globally decentralized governance structure). The “I don’t want to pay taxes on my revenue” comes across as disingenuous, out-of-place & potentially jeopardizing to Maker’s global mission as a global actor. Furthermore, historical voting costs are more of a hindrance for smaller participants than any to-be enforced tax law, so why not put the dialectics that go into minimizing tax payments on revenue towards protocol-level fee saving & L2 solutions for governance. (and yes they are getting closer by the day, Colony specialises in DAO governance and they’re operating on xDai as of now)

content.content: NikKunkel:  Refunding gas fees is a very difficult problem as most decentralized implementations are susceptible to spam attacks which could be used to drain the funding.   The governance reward as written would help to subsidise gas-for-voting by providing DAI to those with MKR locked up in the governance contract (who may then vote.)     NikKunkel:  I really disagree in general with the intent to push through this half-baked idea without the community having reached any consensus on the specifics of the implementation. This proposal needs A LOT of work before it should be inserted into the governance cycle. There’s basically no details at all and just some hand-wavy stuff about governance rewards.   The idea has been discussed for over a month. The MIP lays out the structure of the rewards fairly clearly:  Governance Rewards will be “opt-in”. Users locking their MKR tokens in governance will be able to choose to either receive Governance Rewards or not. The Governance Rewards will be distributed in DAI.   …a portion of DAI that would have been used to buyback and burn MKR being diverted to Governance Rewards. It will be up to Maker Governance to determine the percentage of surplus revenue to be set for rewards…  The MIP should be more explicit on how those rewards are divided between ‘opt-ins’. I think the default assumption is ‘pro rata based on the MKR amount’. But it would be good to state that. This MIP could be accompanied by a technical MIP which defines an implementation, but there is some question over whether that is necessary in this case, it is not a core part of the Maker Protocol, and would pose no technical risk to the protocol beyond a loss of the funds governance diverts to it (so we would obviously start with a test amount). The diversion of FLAP funds is covered by the FlapTap contract defined in the Keg MIPs. My understanding is that @hexonaut has written / adapted a contract to handle the actual distribution of funds based on staked IOU tokens. Saying ‘this needs a lot of work’ and accusing the author of ‘the intent to push through this half-baked idea’ when they just opted not to formally submit it for March and then providing no feedback on the content is unlikely to lead to constructive discussion. I feel like you could have presented your point more diplomatically. If you have input over what we should be doing differently to incentivise MKR Holders to secure the Maker Protocol and participate in governance, I’d love to hear it.

content.content: This proposal and the replies seem to be lacking a fundamental grounding in corporate shareholder governance and political science theory. Incentivized voting does not work well in either field, and the problem only grows worse as complexity is ratcheted up. The reward from voting is too low to incentivize someone who was not previously interested to spend the time to learn about the issues, and the reward doesn’t require it. You just have to vote. It’s as easy as pulling a lever. The voter’s paradox (Paradox of voting - Wikipedia) could also be discussed here, as the issue is similar in nature. An informed vote takes work, and paying someone to vote will not result in more informed votes, but rather just more votes. If the goal is just more votes then I guess it doesn’t matter if they’re dumb votes. However, this problem actually gets worse. These uninformed voters will simply take the path of least resistance by following friends or thought leaders. Half the reason the ethereum community goes with whatever Vitalik says is because 95% of ethereum users can’t understand any of the concepts he’s discussing. They know he is smart and will follow him, right or wrong. I’d prefer not to introduce this issue into the MakerDAO community. All of that is to say, this makes the complicated MakerDAO system perhaps the worst place for this. I would highly recommend pursuing a different path to get more MKR in the voting contract. Top of the mind suggestions would be board of director elections, voting proxies, and the ability to vote from my mobile wallet for the MKR that’s on my hardware wallet. As an aside, I had my MKR in during 2017 or 2018, when the bug was discovered in the contract. I decided since then that my sub 100 MKR would never matter in votes and the risk of smart contract bugs was too great for no reward. A few hundred bucks is not going to change that calculus if you truly believe in the potential of MakerDAO.

content.content: Agree, it seems complicated and it needs probably some sort of air drop for past events.

I’ve been following the Maker governance for weeks now.This proposal is very interesting because it finally strives to move away from the Buyback & Burn model for MKR, which works well in theory (over decades maybe) and awful in practice. Maker has one of the most astounding money generating tools in DeFi, yet somehow its token is teribly aligned with growth. MKR burning does nothing to improve the price, because the project is far from having critical mass and global adoption. At the scae in the next several years the burning may decrease the supply by 2-5% per year at best. This is quite negligible and does not have the desired supply/demand effect for the long-term MKR holders. For short term (6 months to a year) it does not matter at all. And if it does not matter in a raging bull market, ask yourself how it will be in the upcoming bear market. In my view a Buyback and Stake model would work much better. Take a look at Aave tokenomics for reference. The governance rewards the holders for safe-keeping the protocol. MKR holders already incur this risk. But are they rewarded? Theoretically through burning, but practically not. The stability fees provide almost insignificant practical incentives for active governance and protocol safe-keeping. The people who have been participating actively so far without direct payment are truly deserving of better treatment and I applaud the professionalism and due diligence in keeping DAI stable. With a Buyback and Stake model, MKR would be bought on Uniswap and other DEXes at a higher market price, by 5-10% higher. The acquired MKR would then be distributed to MKR governance who stake MKR and actively participate in governance. Thus no inflation occurs and at the same time it creates positive price feedback loops in the markets if done at regular intervals, for example once every 2 weeks. Traders will expect this buying pressure and will sell rather to the protocol at higher prices than to one another as they do now. At about 120 million DAI annualized even 5 million DAI worth of buybacks every 2 weeks will push the price upwards in a healthy way. The sentiment around MKR will change significantly in a positive way. In the last few years it has been horrendous and it is not much better now, being so utterly undervalued at 2 billion DAY marketcap. And if you worry about your local taxes, well what is better - to receive most of the rewards or nothing at all?

content.content: Hi @mahu_victor and welcome to the community,     mahu_victor:  finally strives to move away from the Buyback & Burn model for MKR, which works well in theory (over decades maybe) and awful in practice.   I assume you are referring to the price of MKR which has not kept pace with the success of the Maker ecosystem. The price of MKR, as with all things traded freely, is determined by supply and demand. I will assume you are aware of the term supply/demand balance. In the case of Maker we are in a bit of a pinch at the moment. Due to concerns about regulations and how/if these will impact Maker, the foundation that up until now has governed Maker never did any marketing of the MKR token. There were never any marketing, ICO, airdrops, incentive period - nothing. Only a low number of sales through channels you had to work at how to find, later a pioneering dex. End result is that the MKR token is largely unknown to crypto outside of the circle of stablecoin enthusiasts. And the supply? The basic problem was that starting DeFi summer some of the largest holders decided Maker was boring compared to LP tokens and NFTs. So they started selling just as the crypto market started booming. According to some estimates about 20% of total supply was sold starting in August 2020. The resulting supply/demand balance for MKR is then a high number of tokens sold into a market that does not have widespread knowledge or incentive to buy. While this goes on airdrops, LPs and degen financing steals all attention. The net result is what you see reflected in the poor price of MKR, which has a Price/Earnings ratio of a mediocre real world tech company, completely ignoring the explosive pace of growth. This is partly the reason to be cautious about any MKR minting program as you would just add supply to a market with very limited demand. Moving to a Buyback & Stake model (or any other model) will not fix this. What will fix it is waving goodbye to the foundation, start governing as a community and telling the whole world of the string of successes achieved. Just spreading knowledge of the pace of DAI growth will interest anyone with even a normal sense of greed. This fixes the demand side. The supply side fixes itself as whales eventually run out of MKR to sell.

content.content: I generally agree with your post @mahu_victor. The burning model makes a lot of rational sense in the very long term, but this does not mean it is efficient now. For instance, we haven’t been burning for months now, and we plan not to burn for several more (due to the surplus buffer increase, which is a good move). I agree in particular with:     mahu_victor:  And if you worry about your local taxes, well what is better - to receive most of the rewards or nothing at all?   I frankly think these tax consideration should be ignored in governance. First, the taxation is different in many countries. For example, in several EU countries, DAI dividends and/or crypto (including stablecoins) trading are not taxed; what is taxed is only the ‘final’ event of selling for FIAT. In Malta, crypto is not taxed at all. Second, MakerDAO is an international (since decentralised) organisation, it should not make critical strategic decisions only based on the laws of a given country (even if this country is of critical importance, like the USA). Third, as always proposed, the DAI-rewards would be opt-in. So everybody is free to make their own calculations and evaluate between DAI rewards and other options (e.g., Aave, collateral for farming, just hold, etc).     Planet_X:  Moving to a Buyback & Stake model (or any other model) will not fix this. What will fix it is waving goodbye to the foundation, start governing as a community and telling the whole world of the string of successes achieved.   I agree with this too. But I personally would be even happier if, in conjunction with what you said, I could receive a daily stream of DAI from staking my MKR.

content.content: It’s set up this way because it’s an alternative way to distribute profits other than burning. The Surplus Buffer is set up as the default because that’s effectively where we pay expenses from and is set to a level to manage the risk of the Maker portfolio of lending assets. So once that base level is satisfied (expenses plus risk management) we want to distribute profits to token holders. We’re effectively allowing Governance to split that profit stream between burning and staking however the community sees fit.

content.content: Absolutely, thanks for engaging and asking some good questions!   Sam wrote the code for implementing the rewards based on Uni’s reward program, which does allow users to claim their tokens at their discretion. W/ staking rewards, voting on something in particular is not what’s being rewarded, so I would expect the opposite to be the concerning vector. Basically since people are incentivized to lock their tokens in governance (doesn’t matter which hat), they could leave them there unattended, making it harder to pass new execs. To the extent that it might, we are also in the process of sorting out delegation (which would hopefully come together not long after Staking Rewards, if the community were to support both) and thus ease the worries of idle MKR causing difficulty with passing new execs.
